The diagnosis of asthma is based on the existence of characteristic symptoms '''AND''' the demonstration of reversible airway obstruction (and therefore requires the [[Reasoned request/prescription and choice of a diagnostic test SD-178|performing EFR]]) :

*Symptoms (respiratory discomfort, dyspnoea, wheezing, cough, chest tightness) usually occurring at the same time, of variable intensity over time (paroxysmal), triggered by infections, exercise or exposure to allergens and which may worsen at night (deep night).
*EFR: obstructive ventilatory disorder (FEV1/FVC < 0.7) reversible with bronchodilators (gain of more than 200mL and >12% compared with the initial FEV1 value). A search for bronchial hyper-responsiveness may be discussed if spirometry is normal (with metacholine).

question.title: What is a key criterion for diagnosing asthma?
question.description: The diagnosis of asthma is based on the existence of characteristic symptoms AND the demonstration of reversible airway obstruction

option_a.title: The presence of chronic respiratory symptoms
option_a.description: Symptoms that persist over time and worsen with exercise or exposure to allergens

option_b.title: The presence of wheezing and cough
option_b.description: Symptoms that are typically present at the same time and worsen at night

option_c.title: The presence of bronchial hyper-responsiveness
option_c.description: A condition where the airways are overly sensitive to stimuli

option_d.title: The presence of reversible airway obstruction
option_d.description: A condition where the airways can be opened with bronchodilators

correct_option.title: The presence of reversible airway obstruction
correct_option.description: A condition where the airways can be opened with bronchodilators
